data.title: Digit Span
data.meta_description: 'Digit Span' published in 'Encyclopedia of Clinical Neuropsychology'
data.text:
The term digit span refers both to several important psychological constructs and the names of tests designed to measure these constructs. First and foremost, digit span, along with reaction time, may be viewed as one of the two original paradigms used by experimental psychologists to investigate cognition. The origins of digit span as a psychological construct date back to the work of Gottfried Leibniz (1646–1716). Leibniz suggested that individuals have a finite capacity to prospectively process or hold in mind the information from the environment. He termed this capacity the span of apperception (see JTE Richardson’s paper: Measurements of short-term memory: A historical review. Cortex, 43, 635–650, 2007, for a review.)

In the nineteenth century, Herman Ebbinghaus (1850–1909; 1885/1964 cited in Richardson 2007) was the first cognitive scientist to show how span could be used as an experimental paradigm to...
